During the Remote Learning process, a student may encounter various technical issues that impede their ability to log in or participate in class. While we do not anticipate these will become common occurrences, we want to make every effort to keep you and your childcare provider informed.

The district will send an RCS email message to parents when a significant technical issue arises. Additionally, the district has created a Remote Learning: Current Outages and Problems webpage, available at www.d300.org/Outages. When issues occur, this webpage will be updated to include an explanation of the issue, the schools impacted by the issue, and the anticipated timeline for resolution.

If your student receives childcare from a provider who supports the Remote Learning process, we encourage you to inform your provider about the webpage. This will allow your provider to determine if a technical issue is occurring within the District 300 network or if a student is experiencing an isolated issue, in which case the provider would complete the Remote Learning Tech Support Form.

Have you picked up your new Chromebook and you forgot your password? First, try the password recovery process by answering your security questions. Directions are on the paper provided when picking up the Chromebook. If you cannot retrieve your password by answering the security questions, then fill out the Remote Learning Tech Support Form (www.d300.org/RemoteTechSupport).

This form will allow you to reset your RapidIdentity password, allowing you to log into your Chromebook and access everything you need for Remote Learning, including PowerSchool Learning (formerly Haiku) and Zoom.

The Kane County Health Department (KCHD) has announced that a mobile testing unit managed by the Illinois Department of Public Health will be available on August 2 in the Dundee-Crown High School parking lot to provide Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) tests to the community.

Testing is free and open to all regardless of symptoms.

Testing is open from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. The entrance for the testing is off Amarillo Drive (see map below).

Anyone can be tested.

A phone number and name are required in order to receive testing results. A driver’s license or other form of photo identification is requested.

Testing will be conducted "drive-thru style." Those seeking tests must be seated in their cars with a functioning window. Once you get in line at the site, you will not be permitted to exit your car.

Important Update for the 10 a.m. DCHS Graduation Ceremony

Dear patents and graduates,

Due to inclement weather we have developed a back-up plan if needed. If weather does not permit our scheduled graduation ceremony, we will transition to a dive-thru style ceremony as follows:

1. Cars will be directed by rows to leave their vehicles and follow directions to arrive at the left side ( facing the stage ).

2. Once there, the graduate will exit the vehicle and access the stage via the stairs.

3. Graduates will receive their diploma cover and have their picture taken

4. The family car should pull forward to the other side of the stage to pick up the graduate.

5. Vehicles will then leave the Sears Centre parking lot.

Please note that we currently plan to follow the regular schedule. Please pay attention to emails for updates. For those at the ceremony,
please listen to FM station 88.1 for updates.

Help District 300 Schools for the Next 10 Years by Completing the 2020 Census:

All District 300 community members can help our schools for the next 10 years by completing the 2020 US Census at www.2020Census.gov.

The 2020 Census will direct billions of dollars in federal funding to various school programs and services, including after school programs, bilingual education, classroom technology, the Head Start Program for early childhood education, title grants, that National School Lunch Program, the School Breakfast program, special education grants, and more.

We need your help to count everyone in the District 300 community. Missing one child means missing out on federal funding for that child for the next 10 years.

If you have not already responded to the 2020 Census, please do so at www.20202Census.gov.

For the first time, individuals can respond to the US Census online and via phone, in addition to the mail. Community members can learn about the different methods to respond to the US Census by visiting: https://www.2020census.gov./en/ways-to-respond.html
